description: From Anglo-Norman pencel, reduced form of penuncel. See pennoncel.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A small pennon; a little banner, flag, or streamer. [from 13th c.]
examples: Lances were ornamented with a banderole near the point, which gave them a handsome appearance, these were also called pencells.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A lady's favour or token as worn by a knight. [15thâ€“16th c.]
(rare, obsolete) A knight carrying a pennon.
